Towards adaptive Web scriptable user interfaces for virtual environments

Towards adaptive Web scriptable user interfaces for virtual environments

  • Emad Barsoum1 &
  • Falko Kuester1 

Virtual Reality volume 12, pages55–64(2008)Cite this article

  • 124 Accesses

  • 3 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The vast majority of Web-based technology, its ability to visualize static and time varying information and the pervasive nature of its content have lead the development of applications and user interfaces that port between a broad range of operating systems, databases and devices. However the integration of this immense resource in virtual environments (VEs) remains elusive. In this paper we present a Web scriptable user interface that utilizes Web browser technology to enable the user to search the internet for arbitrary information and to seamlessly augment this information into the VE. WebVRI provides access to the standard data input and query mechanisms offered by conventional Web browsers, with the difference that it generates active texture-skins of the Web contents that can be mapped onto arbitrary surfaces within the environment. Once mapped, the corresponding texture functions as a fully integrated Web-browser that will respond to traditional events such as the selection of links or text input. As a result, any surface within the environment can be turned into a Web-enabled resource that provides access to user-definable data. Using WebVRI, users can merge Web contents into their VE, control its behavior and collaborate with other users inside and outside the VE. This provides a completely new mechanism to access readily available Web-based data, documents, images, animations, simulations and visualization. WebVRI also enables game-based education by providing the ability to create contents rich, pervasive VR-based edutainment environments.

Introduction

Texture mapping has become a predominant technique when it comes to adding content and realism to 3D environments, while keeping the polygonal budget low. However, commonly these textures are statically mapped and therefore fall short to capture time varying information. At the same time this approach provides only one-directional flow of information and therefore prohibits direct interaction with the texture content. In particular, virtual environments (VEs) are now heavily relying on texture-based techniques to further increase the realism of the visualized model or scene.

The emerging need for pervasive data integration, enabling the visualization and analysis of complex time varying information in VEs, requires support for dynamic information exchange in a bi-directional fashion. In other words, users should be able to freely operate on the presented data, reference other data sources and correlate them, regardless of where the information exists. In addition, the vast majority of Web-based technology, its ability to visualize static and time varying information and the pervasive nature of its content have lead to the development of applications and user interfaces that port between a broad range of operating systems, databases and devices. However the integration of this immense resource into virtual environments (VEs) remains elusive.

Leveraging from the capabilities of commodity browsers, the most current advancements in Internet browser technology and its power to interact with different types of information such as text, images, image streams, three-dimensional models and sounds can be combined. This makes internet browsers a universal interface to a vast amount of static and dynamic information. In addition, with the continuous advances of the HTML and DHTML standards, many conventional applications can be encapsulated in a Web pages with JavaScript. Furthermore, the trend is to bring the dynamic and interactive nature of native OS applications to the Web using AJAX (Paulson 2005; Smith 2006) and similar frameworks, which will turn internet browsers into a distributed platform and front-end for many applications. Alternatively, Java applets, ActiveX components and .Net controls can be embedded into HTML pages to provide access to existing applications or to remove some of the limitations that scriptable Web application have. Within the Web context it is then possible to easily write applications that interact with each other and provide a means for users to jointly work in a shared virtual space, regardless of this space existing inside or outside the actual VE system. Interestingly, many Web browsers have the potential to be embedded into other applications. For example, Internet Explorer can be embedded using ActiveX or .Net controls, Mozilla using XPCOM, and for many other open source browsers such as KHTML, FireFox and Mozilla, the available source code can be directly used.

From the perspective of dynamically changing spaces, it is attractive to have a Web centric user interface that is tightly integrated with the VE. This would provide a means to leverage the wealth of data readily available online, while at the same time providing a new form of user interface that can be utilized to change VE content, context and behavior. For example, once the user can navigate the Web from within the VE, it should be possible to select 3D models from Websites that offer appropriate content and to use them to populate or augment the virtual space. Arbitrary models can then be stored in a database or dynamically created and made accessible to the VE via a Web interface, without having to change the VE design, code base or interrupt its execution with a restart.

Within the realm of VE systems, the standard 2D windowing systems can become obtrusive, counter intuitive and distort the 3D realism. Furthermore, VE systems generally deviate from the standard keyboard and mouse paradigms and use more natural input devices. It is therefore important to provide an interface that utilizes the available spatial domain while allowing it to blend with traditional interface components, in order to enrich the still small body of available 3D GUI systems. In order to flexibly adapt to different VEs, the system should easily plug into existing graphical environments and provide users with the flexibility to customize menu behavior at run-time. Considering the wealth of data records and model collections that are now available online, it is desirable to directly draw from these assets.

The concept of WebVRI was developed to provide this level of flexibility. WebVRI can also be used to manage interactive information inside simulation environments. For example, when developing and simulating mechanical components or discussing technical designs, the user can maintain notes, sketches and other information about the target system, using digital noteboards embedded via WebVRI. Since all relevant information can be maintained in an external database, it is then possible for other users to share and contribute ideas in real-time through a Web-enabled interface. This removes the need for all users to be inside the actual VE, allowing for collaboration beyond its traditional bounds. Since models and active texture skins can be exchanged in both directions it is possible to collaborate in immersive and Web-space concurrently. Active texture skins are a representation of a shared document, image or model embedded in a standard Web page, supporting all common html attributes such style sheets and links.

Textures are a critical component for adding scene realism while keeping polygon counts manageable. Beyond data exchange, WebVRI can be used as texture generator, that can translate any Web document into a texture, which subsequently can be mapped to arbitrary surfaces in the scene. The difference is that the texture manager retains knowledge about active elements such as links that were associated with the source document and enables interactive updates to the texture. As a result, active textures implicitly support animations such as flash or gif, which can be utilized to stream arbitrary time-varying data and visualize physical surface effects. Information about active texture skins is maintained by a texture manager and changes are immediately communicated to all applications that share the texture. Users therefore do not have to leave the VE to obtain information generated externally and vice-versa, allowing for a new level of collaborative beyond application and spatial boundaries.

This paper presents a 3D Web interface (WebVRI) for VEs that enables the user to browse the Web for arbitrary information and to embed the queried information into the VE without having to leave the virtual space. WebVRI provides a mechanism to import 3D model geometry linked via a Web page, allowing it to combine both 2D (active texture skins) and 3D content (models) within the VE. This mode allows for the creation of dynamic user interfaces that can be used to modify and control the VE.

Related work

Different strategies for optimizing the use of 2D as well as 3D display technology to interact with multi-dimensional context and content rich information exist. In particular, research in the area of 3D graphical user interfaces has received growing attention (Hamar 2006; Microsoft 2006; Sun 2006; Elmqvist 2003; Chapuis and Roussel 2005; Snowdon 2004). Hamar (2006) provided an application that can rotate, move, and organize in 3D any open application running under Microsoft Windows; Microsoft (2006), Sun (2006), and Elmqvist (2003), also provided a new 3D desktop environment that integrates with the operating system, to replace the current 2D desktop UI, by rendering each application to a texture and then attaching it to a user controllable 3D surface; Chapuis and Roussel (2005) created a feature rich 3D platform for user interface research; Snowdon (2004) and Hagsand (1996) implemented a virtual collaborative environment allowing users, from different locations, to meet in a single VE.

Many of these research projects are based on simply adding depth to the otherwise flat user interface design or by embedding the 2D interface into an otherwise 3D environment. They try to use the third dimension to provide a richer way for data visualization and file organization. The problem with this approach is that there are few 3D UIs that allow for ease of use and productivity, exceeding that of the 2D counterpart. While intriguing in design and appropriate for research use, many impose constraints that limit their usability and usefulness for day-to-day work. This challenge is frequently anchored in the attempt to force 2D interfaces designed for 2D peripherals into their 3D equivalent.

With the need to directly manage and control tasks a new generation of 3D interfaces has emerged (Bowman and Wingrave 2001; Bowman et al. 2001; Dominique and DB 2005). The limitation of some of these approaches is that they statically build a specific user interface to solve a specific problem and that they can not dynamically adapt to changes in the VE. Other researchers have focussed on how to facilitate the mapping of 2D information to 3D objects. For example, Wasson (2006) developed a 3D desktop that allows users to switch seamlessly between virtual desktops in a 3-dimensional manner. The entire desktop representation is converted into a bitmap texture and mapped onto a 3D reference object. This approach effectively maps individual desktops onto different surfaces of single or multiple 3D objects. Apple’s (2006) supports similar techniques.

Angus and Sowizral (1996), combined the open source code of the Mosaic Browser with the InterViews toolkit to provide Web contents inside a VE. The graphical user interface toolkit was tasked with creating a two-dimensional visual interface within a three-dimensional space while supporting mouse input for interaction. In Barsoum and Kuester (2005) the authors explored the creation of active texture skins that can be mapped onto arbitrary surfaces in a scene. The objective was to provide access to static and time-varying Web content via dynamic texture maps. In addition, Hascoet (2001) has proposed advanced visualization and interaction paradigms to support Web browsing through the intensive use of bookmarks and navigation history, his motivation was based on findings that highlight the importance of bookmarks and navigation history. Serge and Daniel in (Rezzonico and Thalmann 1996) explore ways of improving navigation of the Web using a cyberspatial representation based on VRML.

Supporting additional haptic feedback, Poupyrev et al. (1998) describe a virtual notepad for VEs that enables the user to take notes and to augment information on top of the existing scene. Imagine that rather than using a custom made virtual notepad, it would be possible to directly draw from functionality that is readily available for current Web browsers.

Provided with these types of workspaces the development of data fusion strategies that facilitate display of, and interaction with, multi-dimensional data in feature rich VEs is further stimulated for regular desktop environments as well as semi-immersive or fully immersive settings.

Implementation

WebVRI consist of two main components, including a Web browser engine responsible for creating active texture skins and a plug-in for a VR engine that combines texture skins with 3D models. The Web engine is responsible for the acquisition of Web contents and its conversion into active texture skins, resulting in OpenGL compatible textures maps associated with update events. The VR engine itself manages the scene graph, display loop and device loop facilitating system wide input and output events. System design follows an object oriented approach (Gamma et al. 1995; Shalloway and Trott 2004; Krasner and Pope 1988) to allow for changes to algorithms and modules with minimum coding and maintenance overhead.

The idea underlying WebVRI is that the visual representation of a Web page can be generated in an off-screen rendering pass, converted into an image of user specified resolution and returned as an 〈image, pageID〉 pair. This information is then passed to the scenegraph and the image used for regular texture mapping purposes (Fig. 1). For this texture skin to be useful the user must be able to interact with it as if it is a normal Webpage. To facilitate this, dynamic rather than static textures are required that can be continuously streamed to the render system, as user input is captured and passed back to the browser.

Rather than embedding a task specific browser implementation into our framework the presented approach leverages ActiveX controls to extract the desired texture skins from a commodity browser, providing a mechanism for data fusion and extensibility. Consequently, WebVRI provides access to the standard data input and query mechanisms offered by conventional Web browsers with the difference that the browser is tasked with the creation of active texture-skins, which are subsequently passed to the virtual reality system for integration with the existing scene.

Once the texture-skin is mapped onto a surface, the corresponding texture functions as a fully integrated Web-browser that will respond to traditional events such as the selection of links, button clicks, text input or any other interaction supported by the underlying Web browser. As a result, any surface within the environment can be turned into a Web-enabled resource that provides access to user-definable data. Using this technique WebVRI extends the possible application for Web-centric data and automatically inherits advanced feature sets as browser capabilities grow.

Texture skin creation

For the texture skins to function properly, it has to be possible to generate textures for arbitrary Web contents, including regular text, forms, images, videos, animation or combination thereof. At the same time it must be possible to pass user input back to active pages.

Each active texture consists of a texture and I/O context pair that is associated with its own instance of the Web browser engine as well as an active reference address. Active textures inherit all of OpenGL’s texture mapping functionality while adding a texture specific reference frame that is used to map input events to the proper image coordinates that can be passed to the browser for further image specific queries.

The creation of an active texture is broken up into multiple steps, (1) the user creates an instance of an active texture and provides a reference Web address, (2) the Web engine retrieves the corresponding document and renders its contents into an off-screen buffer, (3) the acquired image is converted into a bitmap and an OpenGL compatible texture is returned, including information about the image size and format. Subsequently, (4) this texture is mapped onto arbitrary geometry within the scene (Fig. 2).

The Web browser engine utilizes off-screen render capabilities to remain hidden from the user, as the reference textures are being generated from Web documents. This is achieved by assigning an individual instance of the Web browser engine, in this case an Internet Explorer (IE) ActiveX Control, to each active texture object. Once created, the instance of the Web browser stays active as long as the active texture exists. As soon as an active texture is mapped, two different events can trigger updates to the texture, (1) an update event is initiated when a remote server is pushing new Web contents, as can expected for updates to animated images, video streams, applets, etc. and (2) a user triggered input event such as the selection of a Web link embedded in a page, keyboard input for a form (Fig. 3), or navigation of an interactive application.

As shown in (Fig. 3) an interactive Web page can be mapped to a single polygon. The Web page contains a channel style navigation bar to select which clip should be played and a main panel in which the clip will be displayed.

Interactive updates

Server side push events are supported via a user tunable active textures loop. During each pass of this loop, only browser instances that are visible to the camera are checked to improve performance. If a texture requires updates, a new texture and texture context are automatically generated and updated within the scene. This approach provides for seamless integration of time-varying, Web-based data into the virtual environment. Also, any texture that the user interacts with is priority scheduled for updates, bypassing the active texture loop. As a result, selection of a link causes an instantaneous texture update.

The required frame rate is content and context sensitive and can be user specified for animations and movies. However, image acquisition at too high rates will introduce CPU and memory overhead as well as possible delays while updating the information within the scene graph and OpenGL context, respectively. The default for the user selectable refresh rate is set to 20 Hz for streamed images.

User events are processed in the context of the current viewing position and viewing direction as well as the interaction mode to determine the currently active texture and intended operation. Once identified, the texture context is used to convert screen coordinates or device coordinates (data glove position, etc.) to the proper image coordinates, which are then converted to events and passed to the Web browser to query for further mode specific information, i.e. new image data. Since active textures can be mapped onto arbitrary surfaces within the scene, it is possible to create active wallpaper, floors, ceilings or objects that can fuse real-time Web-based contents into the VE.

Figure 4 shows an example for an active texture space in which all textured surfaces are active, regardless of the type of data being displayed. This illustrates that WebVRI can be used for the development of unique Edutainment environments in VR by providing a means to fuse Web-based context within one information sphere. Users can explore data while playing games, and query Web contents that may aid with providing additional content and context.

Dynamically change VR

The Internet Explorer ActiveX control allows most of the Web page specific events to be captured and redirected. By taking advantage of this feature, it is then possible to dynamically change the virtual environment, introduce new 3D models, behavior and actions into the scene.

All links that the user selects are monitored and action is taken when special objects are discovered. Otherwise, translation of the links is left to the browser. Special objects currently include models in OBJ format Graphics (2006) and python scripts. When an OBJ file is selected, the file with all associated material properties and textures is parsed and a model instance returned that contains the OBJ file information needed for rendering. This model instance is stored in a collection of models which contains previously parsed OBJ files and merged into the scenegraph. In effect, when the user selects an OBJ file its 3D representation will appear floating over the corresponding active texture skin (Web page) and can be repositioned from there.

Each interactive texture can have its own collection of models associated with it, allowing the page designer to control object characteristics (shape and behavior). A model instance, contains a collision method to detect if the device pointer is interacting with it. To simplify the collision detection algorithm, the optimally aligned bounding box enclosing the objet, is intersected with a ray originating from the device pointer. For the purpose of the Web interface, this provides sufficient accuracy while reducing the computational complexity of the collision detector.

Figure 5 shows a WebVRI interactive surface that contains a number of OBJ links Graphics (2006), mapped to a single polygon. Once a model is selected, it will be automatically cloned and added to the scenegraph and its copy subsequently can be modified and freely positioned within the workspace.

Figure 6 shows a Web-based action puzzle game that is displayed using the presented active texture approach. Since the active texture can be seamlessly integrated into a 3D environment and combined with other active textures, it is possible to develop content rich immersive games that allow users to combine game-play with Web-centric knowledge discovery.

WebVRI architecture

Figure 7 provides an overview of the WebVRI system architecture. At execution time, WebVRI loads the model, creates the scene graph and creates the desired number of active textures. For each active texture, an individual instance of the IE ActiveX Control is created, the initial references queried, converted to a bitmap and mapped as a texture skin onto the target geometry. More specifically, after each instance finishes loading, its appropriate Web page is renderer off-screen, captured an converted to a bitmap. The rendering stage that maps from the Web page to the final bitmap always creates a bitmap whose depth corresponds to the depth supported (enabled) by the available hardware. To compensate for hardware differences, the depth resolution of the generated bitmap is verified and if necessary converted to 24 bit with optional support for the alpha channel.

To be able to see animation in any Web page that contains flash animation or video clips, all bitmaps from each instance of IE ActiveX have to be updated periodically. Wile animations will run smoothly for high refresh rates, this comes at the expense of CPU and memory usage, since each update involves a bitmap copy. Similarly, if the refresh rate is too low, animations will flicker or appear to be a slide show. An update rate of 20 Hz worked smoothly for most animations, including flash, while keeping CPU and memory usage bounded. Furthermore, to reduce overhead, textures are only updated if they are in the active viewing frustum.

User interactions with the 3D environment have to be translated into a reference 2D coordinate system relative to the Web browser surface, before messages can be generated for the Web engine. This information is obtained via an un-project and pixel read-back operation to obtain the 3D (x, y, z) position of the mouse relative to the 3D scene before any affine transformation (translation and rotation) in the scene. By knowing the initial position of each surface that contains active textures and those the user has selected, the 3D position can be directly mapped, before affine transformation to its 2D position relative to the Web browser surface. Throughout this process the instances of the browser will remain invisible to the user.

To provide development support on regular desktop systems, WebVRI offers two modes of operations including (1) Web interactive and (2) 3D interactive. While in Web interactive mode the user can interact with the active texture using a keyboard, mouse or 3D pointer interface, as if working with a regular Webpage. The 3D interactive mode provides access to the same conventional interface, but in this case allows free scene manipulation while preventing input to the Web engine. State changes can be easily toggled through a hot key.

Bitmap creation

Different strategies are available to perform a screen capture on a running application. One approach is to capture the window handle of the application, obtain its device context and subsequently to use this device context to create the bitmap. Unfortunately, for this to work, the application must be visible to the user. This causes undesirable problems since the browser window will appear in front of the running VR application whenever a new image is being generated. Furthermore, this approach becomes problematic when many active textures have to be supported simultaneously. WebVRI therefore takes advantage of ActiveX controls to embed the browser capabilities into the framework. In this case a window handle as well as the device context for ActiveX to the host application have to be specified. A bitmap can be created as the device context and appear as a regular device context to the ActiveX control, just as a screen or printer would.

Figure 8 shows this process in more detail. A hidden window is created to host the ActiveX control and a device context from a bitmap which is compatible with the screen in respect to its size, resolution and depth. Two different interfaces have to be implemented for all visible ActiveX controls, consisting of the IViewObject and IOleObject. The IOleObject has information about the size of the ActiveX control, which can be used to obtain the rectangular dimensions in pixel units (HMETRIC unit converted to pixel unit) that the ActiveX Control occupies. IViewObject is the interface responsible for the drawing of the object inside the host application and therefore requires a valid device context, which in this case is the newly created bitmap compatible device context. To obtain the IViewObject and IOleObject interface pointers from the ActiveX control, a two step approach can be employed that first gets the IUnknown interface and subsequently uses the IUnknown interface to query the pointers for IViewObject and IOleObject via the QueryInterface method.

To be able to capture a bitmap from the ActiveX control, the ActiveX itself needs to be visible, however, the host window does not. This allows the bitmap creation to completely take place off-screen. While WebVRI currently uses the IE ActiveX control, the chosen approach does work with any ActiveX control, providing flexibility for the fusion of other data sources. Since it is relatively easy to host any Windows application inside an ActivX Control, this approach can be considered general and not specific to the MS Internet Explorer Web browser.

3D user interface (3D UI)

A new generation of flexible, VR-enabled user interfaces is required to provide intuitive control over the VE (Bowman and Wingrave 2001; Dominique and DB 2005; Poupyrev et al. 2000). This means that an interface is needed to change its contents, context and state. This may include moving objects, creating new objects, changing object behavior and characteristic. It is still controversial if the appropriate interface for this tasks should be natural (Nielsen 1993; Hemphill et al. 1996), if a special set of UIs should be developed for this tasks or both of them mixed. Some assert that WIMP (Windows, Icons, Menus, Pointer) metaphor should be categorically excluded from VEs.

A particular challenge that 3D user interfaces have to address is that the VE or the data that it presents may rapidly change over time. It therefore is important that the interface itself can swiftly adapt to these changes. Beyond data information display and data exchange, WebVRI enables the creation of a Web-scriptable interface that can be dynamically updated as the environment changes. For this purpose phyton scripts are supported that can be tied to links associated with text or objects. Once a link is activated, the script is validated for WebVRI compliance, parsed and handed to the VR-engine, for internal processing. The VR-engine in turn can request or make modifications to the script(s), which can be freely customized per simulation or task and exchanged over the Web at execution time.

Client server architecture

WebVRI was designed from the ground up to support a client server model. Since the output of Web-engine consists of a texture and reference handle an active texture server (running Windows) can be configured and used to stream the results to other systems. Bitmaps were selected as the common data format between the Web browser engine and the VR-engine and are exchanged in combination with the needed event and state information. The advantage of this approach is that the WebVRI engine can be located on its own workstation and stream active textures to other platforms running a range of operating systems. This allows for a clean separation from the render and display nodes used to drive the VE.

Results

WebVRI performance was evaluated and compared against a regular version of Internet Explorer to qualify performance tradeoffs introduced as part of the off-screen rendering, image read-back, streaming and texture mapping stages. A Pentium IV 3.2 GHz system with 1GB of RAM and ATI  ×  600 graphics with 256 MB texture memory was used for system tests. For a single Web page to single polygon mapped scene, the response of the WebVRI environment was nearly identical to that of the stand alone Internet Explorer application running on the same machine. WebVRI was tested in combination with various Web sites containing animations, imagery, text and combinations thereof and the performance differences were indistinguishable to the end user. However, as can be expected, performance decreases as the number of “active” active textures increases. For example, Fig. 4 contains 12 active surfaces, each associated with a hidden instance of internet explorer. In this example, a half second delay for the initial texture update was introduced due to the increased network overhead.

Conclusions

The pervasive nature of Web-based content has lead to the development of applications and user interfaces that port between a broad range of operating systems, databases and devices, while providing intuitive access to static and time-varying information. We have presented a method that fuses Web content with VEs and described the implementation strategy. The resulting framework, titled WebVRI provides access to the standard data input and query mechanisms offered by conventional Web browsers, with the difference that it generates active texture-skins of the Web contents that can be mapped onto arbitrary surfaces within the environment. Once mapped, the corresponding texture functions as a fully integrated Web-browser that will respond to traditional events such as the selection of links or text input and will response to any link that link to an OBJ file by downloading the file with its material and texture if any and render it in the VE system, also we shown how to set some characteristic of the rendered 3D model from the Web page. As a result, any surface within the environment can be turned into a Web-enabled resource that provides access to user-definable data and can be used to change the virtual environment by adding new 3D models or user interfaces.

Since WebVRI is based on commodity browser technology, and does provide direct input and output translation, the generated active textures allow bi-directional data exchange between the WebVRI enabled application and external Web contents. This allows multiple users to form collaborative workspaces via existing Web services, without the need to develop a system specific protocol. In other words, arbitrary applications that provide access to the WebVRI plug-in, can communicate with each other. The presented approach has demonstrated that Web contents can be merged into VE. WebVRI shows good performance results and Web-based video streams can be merged into the running framework at 20 Hz and we anticipate that real-time streaming of high-bandwidth videos will be feasible under PCI-e 16x.
